topic.title: ZeroNet Open Proxy
topic.body:
Am I the only one frustrated when I try to load a zite from this forum only to see NO PEERS? lol

Hopefully this helps.
https://0net.io/

Our team has been running this open proxy for a couple months now as we develop our own services. Its far from ready for any heavy usage, but we're committed to keeping it open and available to host ANY zite of ANY size. So, if you're looking for a stable host for your zite, simply load it using https://0net.io/<your-zite-address>.

FYI - This is a single server, running off-shore, but we're currently working on a migration to a new host with advanced DDoS protection (which will replace Cloudflare). We'll then begin scaling the resources (ie load-balancing multiple servers, data caching, etc), which should improve performance dramatically.

Feedback is always welcome
Cheers!

topic.title: 0net.io Peer Exchange (PEX)
topic.body:
A few people have recently asked to make 0net.io a Bootstrapper as its a **super peer server.** IMO its just not stable enough to be a permanent server for peer exchange *(not yet anyway).* However, I don't see why not **POINT** a DNS entry to one of our **TEST** servers *(as of today, we are no longer testing on it)* and we can always redirect later as we scale up our network.

> Sooo, `pex.0net.io:10443` is now available for **permanent** peer exchange.

---

This was rather inspired by a recent [post from Kaffie](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh/1535778046). I really don't see any need to have to bootstrap from the Clearnet, when `zero://`'s seem to do a better job anyway. 

I also went ahead and enabled the `Bootstrapper` plugin. But I really don't know what this does, as PEX works just fine without it. Could someone please enlighten me as to the added value?

As always, I warmly welcome any feedback and/or suggestions as to how we can help utilize our resources to grow this wonderful community.

Cheers!
d14na

topic.title: DEVS: Is SQLite an Anti-pattern for Zite Data???
Do you use Chrome + Gmail? You might want to check this out
Static Public Key Across Zites
topic.body:
I’d like to propose a question to the Zeronet dev community. From a technical standpoint, what is the purpose of making a user's `public key` UNIQUE on every zite, but the `auth_address` _(aka Bitcoin address)_ the SAME on every zite??

Also curious as to WHY `auth_key` was deprecated; as it would solve the issue with a static "secret" across zites??

---

Opened an issue on Github, but there are  currently `570 open issues`. Oh my!!
https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2217

1534878028_18e4U5WvC4d8Megkv2Sqek9HzrG6T.body:

I've never used sed or awk, but I just took a look at an awk tutorial and I don't know where to begin. Not particularly interested in learning a new language at this moment. Could you help?

BEFORE
`ZeroBlog[changelog, development, zeronet, zero, blog, nofish, github, source:1BLogC9LN4oPDcruNz3qo1ysa133E9AGg8 1599`

AFTER
https://0net.io/1BLogC9LN4oPDcruNz3qo1ysa133E9AGg8

Either the actual file or the linux command to generate would be fantastic

1534889280_19XhqfSemghmQf4m6SZVkw78qW6WK.body:
Thanks for hitting me up on Reddit.

Our team is currently working on a new mobile client for ZeroNet called Zeronet Explorer (https://github.com/d14na/zeronet-explorer). We're about to release our 3rd POC (later this week) before the first MVP (end of Aug, early Sept). 

Compatibility with the current zites is a top priority for us and we've done that with ZeroBlog by adding ZeroFrame (its buggy but mostly working). Finally, we need CDN support and that's were I'm lost. I don't want us to re-invent the wheel, but I don't understand how Merged Sites work. I've seen:

MERGED: CDN
- IFS Cluster
- IFS Cluster
- ZV Cluster

Can you explain how Merged sites function?
---

We created http://127.0.0.1:43110/0cdn.bit
and ideally, what I was looking for was the ability to take:
https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.3.1/jquery.min.js

and make it:
zero://0cdn.bit/ajax/libs/jquery/3.3.1/jquery.min.js
- OR -
http://127.0.0.1:43110/0cdn.bit/ajax/libs/jquery/3.3.1/jquery.min.js

So my last question is, is there any standard for ZeroNet resource linking?

thanks,
d14na

1534891163_1EAD2zXkzgJf6M7xQ4jG5FHCxUTez.body:
@styromaniac yes, we're very much aware of some of the illegal content and have "temporarily" hard-coded redirects for the content obviously no "civilized" person wants to see. we have a project setup to handle this http://127.0.0.1:43110/zerofilters.bit. and it will be integrated with Zeronet Explorer.

My problem with the blocklists that I've seen is that they list the address in plaintext, which basically makes them a directory for that kind of content. Our solution will use an sha hash instead, which can be then be easily queried against before loading any zite.

> When i create zeroid thru your proxy, other users will be able to use it too?

@ssdifnskdjfnsdjk that's an excellent question, and honestly, I have no idea, but "hopefully" NOT. still learning about how zeroid works.

1535451536_1EoqbSwvxRuRKj7vpeK79wuGXdpq2.body:
HAHA!! I've finally managed to hack my users.json back to `d14na`. I couldn't figure out WHERE to put my 32-byte private seed. Apparently it goes into `master_seed`. OKAY, next move it to integrate ZeroID into Zeronet Explorer, so we can ALL be more engaged with the community while on the road. 

ALSO, working to setup a ZeroMe profile today...

> Btw, here are detalils about ZeroNet NewsFeed plugin.

@ssdifnskdjfnsdjk thanks I'll check this out today.

@krixano Okay, that makes complete sense, thanks for the detailed explanation. I'll start experimenting with NewsFeed today.

Argh! So much to learn about ZeroNet before I can actually start implementing. Patience, I guess, is a virtue.

@daniell yeah, I don't know what's up with `index.html` not downloading. I sent you a tar.gz on github, but that too was missing `index.html`. I back in the office today, so I have direct access to the proxy server. I'll post the complete files to github in a just a bit.

@daniell
in case, all you needed was the `index.html`, here's a pastebin https://pastebin.com/gfCzCf2y

>I think it is a serious bug on ZeroNet.

@daniell Yeah, I run into "issues" all the time, but its mostly due to my lack of complete understanding about the inner workings of this platform. I'm digging deeper each day, working my way further down the rabbit hole. Hopefully, when I return to the surface, I'll bring along some added stability :)

1535211258_1P4KkC3wa5xtGD8m2MoBTf5p69G3X.body:
> You and I are guilty of saying why people should switch without giving them every reason to switch.

@styromaniac Zeronet needs a "killer app". I remember when I first started developing on Android back in '09, everyone talked about the "killer app" that would take out iPhone. ummm, it never happened. imo, what allowed Android to compete so successfully with Apple was its ability to iterate quickly and build things faster that Apple devs ever could (because it was an open platform). and users appreciated the bleeding edge apps. imo, Zeronet is currently missing the tools to allow developers to "HAVE AT IT!" and if we don't built it, THEY will never come.

---

I have an idea to build an [Atom plugin](https://atom.io/) that will allow building zites to be as easy as [Dreamweaver](https://www.adobe.com/products/dreamweaver.html) (you know, from way back in the day). Services like Wordpress and Wix are great for allowing ANYONE to produce content, but that's not enough for "real" devs to build APPS (or better yet DApps). IDEs, SDKs and something like NPM are needed to BRING THE DEVS. then I think the Zeronet has a REAL shot at competing with the Clearnet.

@garlic i honestly don't know why you would get the message, "This function is disabled on this proxy!", if you're NOT using a proxy. Also, why is your port `7660` and not the standard `43110`? that might be a clue as to the issue you're having.

1536069895_1KuwwnkAtVrfnyhv8pyGRxLqzNZbE.body:
@lola @nofish pointed me to this a little while back, not sure if it will help you https://github.com/kustomzone/Fuzium

styromaniac i hope you don't mind if I add a few from your list to the roadmap for https://github.com/d14na/zeronet-explorer. `Option to cut off clearnet access` is my fav

> If you create an Android app that has notifications, you have to read this.

@styromaniac i mean F*** YEAH! but it sounds too good to be true

---

**tl;dr how do you solve the battery drain issue?**

---

> SSE fits our needs better than WebSocket

i think WS is a wonderful idea, but it truly SUCKS in reality due to all the "artificial" restrictions placed on communications networks (to "protect" users, as they say), so I get why they would want to stick with long-polling

> We mitigate this problem by asking users to make an exemption from battery optimisations for our app

and that brings us to the BIG problem, aka "the unreasonable compromise that **MOST** users will hardcore flame and leave downright tear-jerking comments about how your app drains their battery"

> Final thought: Every user should be able to choose a “Notification Provider” for every app

**THIS I 100% AGREE WITH...** but, the folks at Mountain View will NEVER (more like 99.99%) support this. and forget about Cupertino. why would they give up all that WONDERFULLY PERSONAL notification data? its quite possibly the greatest "privacy data" treasure trove imaginable, imo 2nd only to SMS. You now have companies like [OneSignal](https://onesignal.com/) building FREE services on top of this, for one reason and one reason alone .. TO SELL YOU TO THE HIGHEST BIDDER (or more like ANYONE who is willing to pay).

*sadly, I don't think anyone has solved the battery drain issue yet...*

**EDIT:** 0Explorer will have something very similar to SSE (p2p NOT client/server), however, I don't think I would turn it on (at least not by default) until the value of the app outweighs the negative battery drain.

> Writting a C++ implementation of Zeronet would make it possible though

this seems inevitable, but I don't know c/c++, so I can only be with you in spirit :p
good luck!

@lola `ImportError: No module named PyQt5`

Tried `apt install python-pyqt5` and `apt install python3-pyqt5`

Then `pip install python-qt5`, but received `The binaries distributed with this version are Windows only,`

Any help getting the "correct" dependencies for Debian/Ubuntu would be appreciated :)

@lola I just tried it again, but still no luck. Even booted up a fresh Ubuntu install to see if that made a difference. I opened an issue on your repo, if that might make it easier to debug.

https://github.com/rllola/ZeronetBrowser/issues/5

> You said that you have pyton 2.7 installed right ?

yes.

---

I have a few jobs running that are taking all of my VM cpu, but once they're done, I'll try again with CentOS (might not make a difference, but what the hell). 

Also, I tried to `locate` PyQt5 and all I see are docs, so I'm really not sure what `apt` is installing (or where its installing it). So I figure I can also try building Qt from source, so that I can properly link the environment `PATH` and hopefully that does it.

I should have more time over the weekend.
So no PyQt5 libraries on CentOS. Next try will be to compile from source on Ubuntu. I'll let you know.

> Yes they are self-contained and you can still update ZeroNet code and audit it !

okay, that's really fantastic! I haven't had time this week _(juggling a bunch of projects),_ but I'm looking forward to using the browser for some upcoming testing, where I want a clean environment _(from a Fist-time User perspective)._ I'll definitely post detailed feedback at that time.

---

I'm not very familiar with Travis _(or test platforms for that matter),_ but I'll do some digging and see what I can recommend.

> Site on Zeronet with description of the project, donation qrcode and downloading latest version of it.

i can handle that

1536120595_1EAD2zXkzgJf6M7xQ4jG5FHCxUTez.body:
> Using a specific domain name (pex.0net.io) would entirely defeat the purpose of my idea.

@kaffie i see, understood. `zero://zero.booth.moe#f36ca555bee6ba216b14d10f38c16f7769ff064e0e37d887603548cc2e64191d:443` was the only tracker from my client list that I got working with pex. *(btw, I love the music there lol).* perhaps a hybrid solution would work best, as IP addresses can of course be censored very easily by ISPs; but DNS entries are easier to redirect *(at least until the domain gets confiscated by govt).* once I have a permanent IP address that's reasonably protected against censorship, I'll happily include it in a list of "official" trackers. *of course anyone who really wants that IP can just ping the domain.*

---

thanks for explaining the bootstrapper plugin. for convenience, `tracker.0net.io` is also currently pointing to the same server.

> It's working great

@kaffie nice!

---

I spent the whole day working/studying/analyzing Peer Exchange and the result ... it sucks, BAADDD lol This is NOT news to anyone who's worked with P2P networks I'm sure, but there HAS to be a better way to rate and report the quality of peers. 

its NOT ideal, but I'm seriously considering running nodes (likely via the [SUPeer project](http://127.0.0.1:43110/supeer.bit)) to continuously analyze the network (maybe for the TOP100 zites) and report on its peer quality ; similar to the trackers list shown on `1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D`. an "open-source" smart contract (yeah, i love to build on Ethereum) would then be publicly accessible to query a zite for "quality" peers. ANYONE running one of these "analysis" nodes could provide a similar list (NOT necessarily via blockchain) and eventually these lists would be rated themselves by the community. aside for the addition of "quality" ratings, i guess it would be identical to the centralized trackers used today, but on top of a blockchain that cannot ever go off-line.

i like @krixano's plan for trusted peers as a reasonable compromise to the certificate authority decentralization problem. perhaps that pure p2p solution could apply here as well.

1536035206_1LiBAqfmPSAEhoFj2fM3iMEZe5uzZ.body:
> Botnets can seed zites and say they don't have the files, then recommend another peer from the same botnet.

@daniell interesting theory. are there now, or have there ever been any attempts at creating a "centralized list" of malicious peers? in the blockchain community, malicious actors do harm just because they can. sometimes the worst harm can be done [unintentionally](https://mashable.com/2017/11/08/ethereum-parity-bug). eventually it WILL come here. best to be prepared

> Problem is, a centralized list ruins decentralization, which is the primary goal. 

@shitchell I agree! My *issue* is **specifically** regarding the use of trackers. Aren't they centralized servers? 

> But if you maintain a more decentralized list to combat a flaw in some decentralized network

I'm not so much trying to solve the problem (cause I really don't know how), as much as move one step further in the right direction. I don't think anyone really KNOWS who's running those trackers; some of them could potentially be honeypots just idling collecting data for some future nefarious purpose, i dunno. I do believe that blockchains DO improve on the overall transparency of the "connected" services we deal with day-to-day. So although they ARE centrally controlled/managed; they are mostly open-source (so easily auditable) and heavily protected from censorship, which is NOT something we have today.

1536131965_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6n.body:
@krixano so I'm at the KxoNetwork (beta) [registration page](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P/?/create-id) but when I click `CREATE ID` the progress just keeps spinning.

I'm not even sure if PeerMessage is installed correctly. It could very easily be a local issue, as I'm behind a router and running a VPN. Is there a simple/quick test zite for PM?
@robione restarted ZeroNet again and this time it worked flawlessly. thanks!

1536308470_1EAD2zXkzgJf6M7xQ4jG5FHCxUTez.body:
> Why Diaspora moved from MongoDB to MySQL

@nofish that was a great read! hadn't heard of Diaspora. its always good to have a reference before exploring ideas as to not duplicate "failed" efforts.

> a lot of investigation to figure out that we were using MongoDB the wrong way.

that is really my key takeaway from the article. but as this was written 5-years ago, I'm fairly certain MongoDb couldn't properly serve their needs at the time. I remember a time when I couldn't use MySQL in production, because it didn't have **stored procedures** lol. things are very, VERY different today; and NoSQL is much more mature.

sooo, I'm not a DBA and have far from the expertise to really KNOW what I'm talking about here. but I just get a bad feeling as I try to understand and rationalize the place SQLite plays in the **BIG picture (particularly scalability)** of the Zeronet and what I think ***COULD*** be possible in terms of near **REAL-TIME** communication. 

Thank you for the insight *(I'll have to dig a bit deeper to fully understand the disadvantages you mention)* and I'll definitely keep all of it under consideration as I continue to explore and develop. With all of the great developers in this community, everyday on the Zeronet seems to be more exciting than the last...

---

**EDIT:** Playing a bit with [Diaspora](https://diasporafoundation.org/) .. meh .. each Pod uses the [Federation](https://bit.ly/2MWEspj) to inter-link the network and they call it decentralized?? shame on them, more like distributed. Once you're within a Pod (eg https://diasp.org/), there is very little decentralization (if ANY). Zeronet has them beat on decentralized network; hands down (nothing to see there)...

1536337537_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body: @gitcenter keep getting "NO PEERS FOUND". its working from 0net.io, but then I can't sign in from there. any way to just VIEW the zite, without having to "Login"? Or can that be added? thanks!

@gitcenter 0net.io has the plugin, but it still requires a login. any way to allow just a `view-only` mode?

also, what's the license on the [plugin,](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Plugin-PeerMessage)? I'd like to review the source for integration into 0Explorer and another client. MIT? GPL? thanks!

I like the ISP (been with them for a long time) because they're one of the best in Panama, which I consider the MOST anti-censorship jurisdiction, but they're really NOT cooperating with our current needs very well and we have much more "reasonable" alternatives now. regardless, once we upgrade (one way or another), 0net.io will be able to seed more than a few TiBs without a problem.

@daniell Multiuser plugin IS enabled, so that everyone CAN'T update the proxy (eg increasing zite limits). with that plugin, i thought every user shared the same private key. no? I really don't understand how it can work, unless pks are stored in localstorage (the browser).

1536836748_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUt.body:
> Nofish raised the limit of gzip file at rev3582

oh, I see.

---

okay, so 0net.io has been updated to `rev3612` from `rev3550`. it was NOT a smooth upgrade as I guess some database had to get rebuilt for each and every zite, but it kept hanging the bootstrapping process. eg

```
[16:32:02] Site:1MaiL5..Ju27 ContentDb init: 0.002s, found files: 0, sites: 1064
[16:32:02] Site:1MaiL5..Ju27 ContentDb not initialized, load files from filesystem
```

So, had to load in a few dozens zites at a time until they were all re-synced. I really should have done this during off-hours, but I guess on a decentralized system there's no such thing. Anyway, it should be good now. coordinated with the ISP this week and it looks like they'll have our upgrades completed over the next few days. should improve performance, but most of all, **we'll start FULL SEEDING the ~1,000 zites registered here now.**

@blurhy can you verify https://0net.io/1CjMsvhJ2JsV4B5qo3FDHnF3mvRCcHuxBn/ is working as it should? thanks!

> Uh,the db is still empty.I saw the json.gz files in the result of fileList.That means the Horizon is up to date.Maybe the zeronet is still building database.

@blurhy we migrated to a new VPS over the weekend, files are still syncing, but I just tested https://0net.io/1HoRiznsHbJAqs2bmrVcSd79NTGVFp4Ju2, and *seems* to be working okay. can you please verify?

1536996722_1J2sR4SBGqowvrAGW2gmfyd1BsjQL.body:
> Kiwipedia is an attempt to bring Wikipedia onto ZeroNet.

@kaffie how does this work? I don't see any articles. can you link one as an example? thanks!

1536955600_14mSHL2TBcqcLNcfpmg5jyGVS9RZi.body: One of the features we're building into [Zeronet Explorer,](http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeronetexplorer.bit) is to alert/notify the user anytime they visit a NEW zite (including clicking on links). So, before visiting a place that appears to be familiar but actually isn't, you would get an alert. The alert would have `content.json` data, eg title and description of the zite, at which point you can choose to continue or not.

1536996506_1J2sR4SBGqowvrAGW2gmfyd1BsjQL.body:
> There are 3 types of "Search Engines" in ZeroNet... 3. Centralized Search Engine

@krixano Ahh, so there ARE engines that crawl ALL zites to index. Can these centralized servers be "decentralized"? Basically, a cluster of nodes that help in contributing to the indexing and reporting? Just a thought.

1537204255_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2.body:
> We're fortunate to have them.

@robione i use Cloudflare for (i think) every one of my clearnet sites. and I'm very fortunate to have them providing the service they do. but @freeperson is 100% right, they ARE the MITM, the largest that I'm aware of on the Internet. so why wouldn't the 3-letter agencies just make their lives sooo much easier and squeeze the hell-out-of-em (how long can you resist the DOJ or the NSA??) for any info they need. personally, I'd rather a world where we didn't need CF (fyi, their DDoS services start at US$200/mo) and everyone could reliably depend on the security and scalability of the Zeronet.

> Now how about we get back to the IPFS discussion that was hijacked by nonsense FUD.

@robione had no intentions of hijacking anything. however, from my experience, 90%+ of people (that I personally know, NOT representative of their userbase) that use Cloudflare DO NOT realize that this company has unencrypted access to ALL their communication. and they're very surprise by that! they still use and love the service, because it avoids them having to deal with SSL certs, Apache configs, etc. just want to help keep people educated about the facts, which I see nothing wrong with. i think Cloudflare's crypto services are a wonderful addition to an already wonderful service.

Just want to mention another WOT reference. [#bitcoin-otc](https://www.bitcoin-otc.com/trust.php) worked very well in the early days of Bitcoin (before exchanges existed) online trading.

@djinn So just a quick note on this. One of the features I added with http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeronetexplorer.bit was the ability to download the `content.json` file and view the title and description **BEFORE** downloading all of the content. 

As you know, many zites are simply public keys (Bitcoin) addresses, which make them very hard to discern what content you're about to view. Perhaps this could be added to the Core Client as a Splash Page feature for NEW zites.

1543909269_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJV.body:
> the first zite is owned on 0net.io and it links on zer0net; I don't understand their relation, in particular what it's zer0net

@schiz0 Your confusion is more than understandable. Here is a quick breakdown, which we are working to make clearer on our official portals.

- ZeroNet (Core) is the "official" Zeronet client
- Zer0net is a brand created by D14na (Decentralization Authority) to house all of our products and services
- 0net.io is a public proxy under the Zer0net brand

---

> some page template not complete.

@polar https://zer0net.com was our original promotional (clearnet) site for Zer0net, but we have since shifted our focus to utilizing the proxy (0net.io) to host our promo/landing pages.

---

> is 0net.io official?

@ornataweaver Our proxy is NOT "official", however, we are currently hosting the "official" client using the Multi-user Plugin, which I DON'T recommend you use for anything private or sensitive (our proxy runs on a VPS, so our ISP's admins also have access to the proxy and its contents). 

We are working on a new "mobile-optimized" client (with built-in VPN) to replace the current proxy. The core client/proxy will continue to be available at https://core.0net.io/<zite-address> and supported by our team.

1547014808_1JGp4gaBwTZ6rjuLytHJ1o9C93kfk.body:
tl;dr perhaps [Infura](https://infura.io/) could server as an ideal "meek bridge" for the Zeronet.

---

@lowg Zeronet clients will need to support the ability to "obfuscate" data requests, similar to ["meek bridges"](https://blog.torproject.org/how-use-meek-pluggable-transport) on Tor. Are there any popular decentralized services currently unfiltered by the GFW? I'd recommend creating a short list of candidates then looking into integrations with Zeronet's peer discovery system.

---

Those following crypto may have heard that [Rinkeby just forked to Constantinople](https://www.reddit.com/r/ethereum/comments/ae6nbv/rinkeby_just_switched_over_to_constantinople/), a proof-of-stake consensus network for Ethereum. I'm more than ready to contribute to building a __blockchain-based tracker__, ideally, but not necessarily using the new Rinkeby POS for peer discovery. 

Of course, individual peers can/will continue to be censored, however, this becomes exponentially more difficult as the network grows.

> it'd be quite counterproductive to ban access to the entire Ethereum network

Here is the latest distribution of Ethereum nodes:
https://ethernodes.org/network/1

With Mainland China currently at #2, running close to 16% of ALL nodes, it seems very promising to consider this a permanent anti-censorship solution (really for ANY country NOT censoring Ethereum).

1550686723_1EpY11syeaKbwRSNqv9tU1ZxoU1mo.body:
We've been using our own http://127.0.0.1:43110/zitetags.bit for about 6-months now. It obviously relies on some Clearnet resources, but there's really no way around that yet. 

---

Its not yet available to the public, but like @loligod, we've registered and maintained a few registrations for community members (and happy to do so for anyone else). We're still finishing our new certid system; then anyone will be able to register, manage, update, transfer, etc. 

---

FYI, its looking more and more likely that it will be 100% free (as in beer); but there are obvious challenges with that, to prevent abuse. Plus, we're still sorting the custodial security issues with namecoin private keys.

As always, feedback is welcome!

1551837029_1LiBAqfmPSAEhoFj2fM3iMEZe5uzZ.body:
> Why is it bad if corporations make a blockchain network?

@viridian i'm always humored when corps create "private" networks and call it blockchain. the main point of blockchain is decentralization. I could understand even a delegated blockchain, eg, [Ripple Network](https://ripple.com/); but something like [Quorum](https://www.jpmorgan.com/country/US/en/Quorum) (JP Morgan's baby) is so utterly ridiculous to call it a blockchain, when its completely owned, run and managed by a single entity.

> having some infrastructure at least semi-centralized

I believe this is the ideal, as you can then marry the best of both worlds, and make a "beautiful" baby

1565037100_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
tl;dr how can zeronet run with cpu multi-threading?

---

this may be slightly off-topic, but what can be done to __improve the CPU usage?__ its currently single-threaded, creating a horrible bottleneck for all the background processes that are constantly running. this becomes a problem as number of seeds increases/user load increases. looking at `top` on the vps hosting __0net.io [https://status.0net.io/]__, its just constantly pegged at 100% for ONLY ONE CPU, there are 7 doing basically nothing @ 1% (also the RAM hasn't made much difference past 4GB). this obviously has nothing to do with your (very valid) RAM usage question, but it would be a huge performance boost (for ALL public proxies) if zeronet were able to run on multiple cpus. 

any suggestions as to libraries that could offer such support would be greatly appreciated. or if @nofish thinks this is high enough a priority to create an official [bounty](https://zeronet.io/docs/help_zeronet/donate/), I would certainly offer my full support

1569204638_1LJMKSLPgM8fqQSMRrLzWB2DhVm1z.body:
https://www.namecoin.org/download/

if you're ok with binaries, then its super simple, otherwise, get your compiler ready and maybe some redbull

Here are the build instructions
https://github.com/namecoin/namecoin-core/blob/master/doc/build-unix.md

If you're ONLY looking to "help out" by running a node, then I'd do away with the __wallet__ `--disable-wallet` and __GUI;__ you can then avoid dealing with __Berkeley DB__ and __Qt__ respectively, which imo is where the bulk of compiler problems come in.

Good luck!

> You can also use the Name.Yo service instead

I'm not familiar with this service. DDG wasn't very helpful. How can I get more info?
after `~/namecoind -daemon`, you can test using the CLI `namecoin-cli getblockchaininfo`

> Name.YO (with capital O) is a domain name service for ZeroNet

oh, i see. i'll check it out later. can you provide a link to the plugin's source?
